description: Posts from Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

items.title: This officer will lose 30 days of work for punching someone in...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

This officer will lose 30 days of work for punching someone in the face and for using a Taser while the person was already in handcuffs. Things the rest of us could be charged with felonies for. A badge should not justify violence.

#HoldCopsAccountable #DefundThePolice #CAAPV #EndPoliceViolence

https://www.denverpost.com/…/denver-police-use-of-force-t…/…

A Denver police officer will lose 30 days of work for unnecessarily punching a man in the face and then Tasing the man in the back after he was already handcuffed.

denverpost.com

Denver police officer suspended for Tasing man in the back after he was handcuffed

#HoldCopsAccountable #SB217 #CAAPV

items.title: Proud of #CAAPV’s own Jes Jones for speaking out against...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Proud of #CAAPV’s own Jes Jones for speaking out against DPD’s efforts to violently silence protesters, and grateful for the work of National Lawyers Guild of Colorado for their work to protect protestors against DPD’s relentless violence.

In the National Lawyers Guild statement, Jones takes on Polis for implying that protesters are criminal terrorists: "To have the Governor of Colorado equate property destruction as terrorism yet refuse to condemn police killings of unarmed... Black men is unacceptable. Property can be replaced, Black Lives cannot," she maintains.

...

“The arrests are violent, resulting in broken bones and other serious injuries. The criminal charges are being inflated to increasingly serious offenses. Protesters are being forced to risk their safety and freedom in order to exercise their right to free speech," said Jessica Jones — a local criminal defense attorney and volunteer organizer for the Colorado NLG. "It is a sad paradox that protesters experience police violence as they protest police violence."

In addition to violent policing tactics in the name of crowd-control, Denver Police recently began invoking a little-used ordinance that was originally passed in anticipation of the 2008 Democratic National Convention protests. The law bans activists from carrying protective equipment, chains, and bike locks.

"This ordinance has allowed police to criminalize activists before a protest has even started," said Jones.

https://www.westword.com/…/denver-protest-arrests-likened-t…

See MorePossession of a helmet can allegedly lead to an arrest.

westword.com

Claim: Denver Police Busting Protesters for Protecting Themselves

Possession of a helmet can allegedly lead to an arrest.Possession of a helmet can allegedly lead to an arrest.

items.content_html:

“The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, which issues waivers to departments so they can use the sedative in that manner, in July reopened an investigation into McClain’s case and, in September, into the use of the substance by paramedics statewide. Paramedics have used ketamine in an EMS setting more than 900 times in the past three years, according to the department.”

https://www.denverpost.com/…/elijah-mcclain-ketamine-ban-a…/

Aurora City Council banned the city’s emergency responders from using ketamine until an independent investigation into the death of Elijah McClain is complete.

items.title: “When police officers openly discuss with one another their...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

“When police officers openly discuss with one another their disdain for one group of citizens that they are sworn to serve and protect, and make jokes about killing those citizens for ‘paid vacation leave,’ they normalize police misconduct and murder,” Schielke said in a statement. “Cop jokes about some lives not mattering inevitably fosters a culture of police officers who are much more willing to pull the trigger on those same lives later.”

https://www.denverpost.com/…/hells-angels-lawsuit-settleme…/

Five Colorado police agencies paid $25,000 and issued an apology to a Hells Angels member after an officer two years ago joked that he’d shoot the man to get “paid vacation.”

items.title: And for this week's #CAAPV #DidYouKnow: even when someone...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

And for this week's #CAAPV #DidYouKnow: even when someone charged with a crime "wins," their lives are never the same, nor are their pocketbooks.

If we are to #HoldCopsAccountable, we must remember that #DAsAreCopsToo and work to hold them accountable, too.

items.title: What happened? The officer lost two days of pay, and will be...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

What happened? The officer lost two days of pay, and will be back on the street responding to our vulnerable citizens, including victims of domestic violence. #CAAPV #HoldCopsAccountable #DefundThePolice

“Cochran then responded in a text: “I’ll bet if I beat your ass on the regular, you’d be incapable of staying away from me.”

Cochran, who joined the department in 2017, told internal affairs investigators that the woman had confided in him that she had been in unhealthy rela...tionships in the past and that he was trying to “indicate he was better than the previous men she had dated,” his disciplinary letter states. He said the text he sent was poorly worded.”

items.title: Roughly 14% of DPD’s dispatch was for violent crime (which,...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Roughly 14% of DPD’s dispatch was for violent crime (which, mind you, includes “riots”), which account for about 17% of officer’s time on the street.

Do not succumb to the fearmongering that if we defund the police that we will be unsafe. It’s simply untrue.

#CAAPV #DefundThePolice #AbolitionNow

...

https://www.denverpost.com/…/denver-police-officer-time-jo…/

See MoreThough violent crime generates the most headlines, Denver’s patrol officers spent more than 80% of their time dealing with other less serious complaints and a wide array of community tasks.

denverpost.com

How do cops spend their time? As Denver debates police funding, these numbers offer an inside look

items.title: From Laurie Kepros. Stand in solidarity Thursday, 9/24, #CAAPV! ...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

From Laurie Kepros. Stand in solidarity Thursday, 9/24, #CAAPV!

“In case it interests, THURSDAY 9/24/20 from 8am to 2pm, there will be a protest at the 10th Circuit in Denver in opposition to the court's August decision in Millard erroneously finding Colorado's sex offender registry is not punishment. For more details contact WAR at the email address below. All are welcome, masks are encouraged:
On Thursday, September 24, 2020, Women Against Registry and others dedicated to ...change in America’s sexual offense registration laws will be in front of the 10th Circuit Appeals Court building from 8 AM to 2 PM to protest the 10th Circuit’s ruling. The message is simple – the registry IS punishment. As we know it has altered the lives of human beings who merely want to have their lives fully restored.

We invite each and every person experiencing the punitiveness and stigma of registration to join us. Each man, woman or child can make a difference. Begin right now making plans to be part of the demonstration and/or donating to the initiative to help with travel, lodging, materials and brochures which are being designed as we speak. It will be a great time to meet others from like-minded organizations and be a part of something BIG!
Let us know if you will be joining us so that we can keep you apprised of on-going plans and developments.

For more information, contact... 10thcirteam@warfamilyfoundation.org”

See More

After 23 years, 6 trials, and four death sentences all secured through deplorable prosecutorial misconduct, Curtis is free. And thankfully living proof of why our states are not equipped to kill.

items.title: A successful #DecarcerationDayOfAction. Thanks to Joyce...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

A successful #DecarcerationDayOfAction. Thanks to Joyce Akhahenda, Dr. Apryl Alexander, Party for Socialism and Liberation - Denver, Elisabeth Epps/Colorado Freedom Fund, Abron from Second Chance Center, and Gerry for speaking truth to power and for telling beautiful stories of humanity and redemption.

As #CAAPV’s own Nicole Duncan said:

There are 36,000 people in jails and prisons in Colorado (this does not include juveniles and people in ICE Detention).

...

830 have tested positive for Covid (these are the known numbers).

3 have died (these are the known numbers).

You’ve seen what happens to the people we can see on the media. We see how people are treated out in the open. I can’t imagine the treatment of the people I can’t see.

We have to fight for the ones we can’t see.
We have to fight for the ones we can’t see.
We have to fight for the ones we can’t see.

#CAAPV #decarcerationday #FreeThemAll #covidjustice #carenotcages #endmassincarceration #COVIDcolorado #doyourpart #bringourneighborshome #redemptionisreal #clemencyiscompassion

items.title: Anthony is an 84-year-old grandfather who has spent 30 years...
items.content_html:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Anthony is an 84-year-old grandfather who has spent 30 years incarcerated for a series of robberies and spends each day confined in a wheelchair in his cell in Sterling, terrified of catching COVID-19.

“I fear the way the COVID-19 has ravaged this facility. It has put a great deal of us at-risk adult in harms way. For me, this can be a potential death sentence. At my age and with underlying health conditions, this feels like cruel and unusual punishment.”

— Anthony Martinez...

Anthony Martinez is an 84-year-old grandfather suffering from renal failure, as well as other serious medical conditions including dementia. He is currently incarcerated in the Sterling Correctional Facility, site of one of Colorado’s largest COVID-19 outbreaks with almost 600 active COVID-19 cases. He and his family are understandably terrified that he will catch the virus and die.

Anthony has spent over 30 years behind bars for a series of robberies. He has paid a substantial debt to society for these crimes. With his age and infirmity, no one can argue he is a public safety risk, but he has a substantial risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from COVID-19 if he remains incarcerated. Despite this, his special needs parole application was denied.

Anthony’s niece, Kelly, has a room in her home waiting for him to spend his final years. She says, “Only nine people on the side of the prison where my uncle is currently held are still negative for COVID-19. It’s all around him and it’s only a matter of time before he gets sick. I know my uncle is lonely and isolated. He uses a wheelchair, is hard of hearing and is locked in his cell almost all day. Prison is no place for elderly people. Please, I need my uncle home before he dies.”

In the midst of this public health crisis, incarcerated people as vulnerable as Anthony, could and should be immediately released to safely live out their remaining years with family. #decarcerationday #FreeThemAll #covidjustice #carenotcages #endmassincarceration #COVIDcolorado #doyourpart #bringourneighborshome #redemptionisreal #clemencyiscompassion
